newsitem.title: CHINA: HK businesses urge non-intervention in industry.
newsitem.headline: HK businesses urge non-intervention in industry.

text.p: Hong Kong's business community urged the territory's leader Tung Chee-hwa on Wednesday not to meddle in industry, saying the hands-off policy adopted in the past had been successful.
The General Chamber of Commerce said chairman James Tien had written to Tung to air its views on industrial policy.
"He pointed out that few industrialists in Hong Kong would like to see the government in the driver's seat of industrial development," the chamber's statement said.
"Rather, they advocate a middle-of-the-road approach of appropriate government support to industry," it said.
The chamber called for minimum market intervention.
Hong Kong, formerly a British colony, reverted to China on July 1. The former administration adopted a laissez faire policy but provided certain support to industry.
China-appointed Tung has signalled he will take a greater interest in industrial development policy.
"The government's industrial policy so far has been quite successful, otherwise we won't be as prosperous as we are now," the Chamber of Commerce quoted Tien's letter as saying.
The chamber, however, also called for government support to help industry adjust to economic changes.
"In the end, what Hong Kong needs is a policy that provides the environment for Hong Kong to be a centre for innovation in both services and manufacturing," it said.
